a.g: [All] praise is [due] to Allah, who has sent down upon His Servant the Book and has not made therein any deviance.
[He has made it] straight, to warn of severe punishment from Him and to give good tidings to the believers who do righteous deeds that they will have a good reward
In which they will remain forever
And to warn those who say, "Allah has taken a son."
They have no knowledge of it, nor had their fathers. Grave is the word that comes out of their mouths; they speak not except a lie.
Then perhaps you would kill yourself through grief over them, [O Muhammad], if they do not believe in this message, [and] out of sorrow.
Indeed, We have made that which is on the earth adornment for it that We may test them [as to] which of them is best in deed.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
والمقصود من هذا: أن الزيادة على قدر الحاجة إنما تأتيك ابتلاء وفتنة لينظر الله إليك ماذا تعمل فيه، وقدر الحاجة يأتيك رفقاً بك، فلا تغفل عن الفرق بين الرفق والابتلاء. قال الله تعالى: " إنا جعلنا ما على الأرض زينة لها لنبلوهم أيهم أحسن عملاً ". وقد قال صلى الله عليه وسلم: " لا حق لابن آدم إلا في ثلاث: طعام يقيم صلبه، وثوب يواري عورته، وبيت يكنه، فما زاد فهو حساب". فإذن أنت في أخذ قدر الحاجة من هذه الثلاث مثاب، وفيما زاد عليه أن لم تعصر الله متعرض للحساب، وإن عصيت الله فأنت متعرض للعقاب.
Indeed, the intended meaning of this is: that what comes to you beyond the measure of need [qadr al-haja] comes only as a trial [ibtila'] and a test [fitna], so that Allah may look upon you—what you will do with it. And the measure of need comes to you as a gentleness [rifq] towards you. So do not be heedless of the distinction between gentleness [rifq] and trial [ibtila']. Allah, the Exalted, has said: "Indeed, We have made that which is on the earth an adornment for it, that We may test [nablūhum] them as to which of them is best in deed." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, has said: "The son of Adam has no right except to three things: food to sustain his spine, a garment to cover his nakedness, and a house to shelter him. Whatever is beyond that is for accounting [hisab]." Therefore, you, in taking the measure of need [qadr al-haja] from these three, are rewarded. And as for what is beyond that, if you do not disobey Allah, you are exposed to accounting [hisab]; and if you disobey Allah, you are exposed to punishment ['iqab].

a.g: And indeed, We will make that which is upon it [into] a barren ground.
Or have you thought that the companions of the cave and the inscription were, among Our signs, a wonder?
[Mention] when the youths retreated to the cave and said, "Our Lord, grant us from Yourself mercy and prepare for us from our affair right guidance."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وتقول عند ابتداء الأمور ﴿ ربنا آتنا من لدنك رحمة وهيىء لنا من أمرنا رشدا ﴾
Indeed, say at the commencement of affairs: "Our Lord, grant us from Your presence a mercy [rahma] and prepare for us from our affair a right guidance [rushd]."

a.g: So We cast [a cover of sleep] over their ears within the cave for a number of years.
Then We awakened them that We might show which of the two factions was most precise in calculating what [extent] they had remained in time.
It is We who relate to you, [O Muhammad], their story in truth. Indeed, they were youths who believed in their Lord, and We increased them in guidance.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وقد كان الشيوخ يقدمون الشباب بالعلم. كان عمر بن الخطاب رضي الله عنه يقدم ابن عباس وهو حديث السن على أكابر الصحابة ويسأله دونهم وقال ابن عباس رضي الله عنهما: ما آتي الله عز وجل عبدا علما إلا شابا والخير كله في الشباب ثم تلا قوله عز وجل: ﴿ إنهم فتية آمنوا بربهم وزدناهم هدى ﴾ {}
Indeed, the elders [shuyukh] would give precedence to the youth in matters of knowledge [‘ilm]. ‘Umar ibn al-Khattab, may God be pleased with him, would give precedence to Ibn ‘Abbas, while he was of tender age, over the great Companions, and would ask him instead of them. And Ibn ‘Abbas, may God be pleased with them both, said: "God, Mighty and Majestic, does not grant a servant knowledge [‘ilm] except while he is young, and all good is in youth." Then he recited His, Mighty and Majestic, saying: **"Indeed, they were youths [fityah] who believed in their Lord, and We increased them in guidance [huda]."**

a.g: And We made firm their hearts when they stood up and said, "Our Lord is the Lord of the heavens and the earth. Never will we invoke besides Him any deity. We would have certainly spoken, then, an excessive transgression.
These, our people, have taken besides Him deities. Why do they not bring for [worship of] them a clear authority? And who is more unjust than one who invents about Allah a lie?"

[The youths said to one another], "And when you have withdrawn from them and that which they worship other than Allah, retreat to the cave. Your Lord will spread out for you of His mercy and will prepare for you from your affair facility."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
ي أصحاب الكهف وإذا اعتزلتموهم وما يعبدون إلا الله فأووا إلى الكهف ينشر لكم ربكم من رحمته أمرهم بالعزلة وقد اعتزل نبينا صلى الله عليه وسلم قريشا لما آذوه وجفوه ودخل الشعب وأمر أصحابه باعتزالهم والهجرة إلى أرض الحبشة حديث اعتزاله صلى الله عليه وسلم قريشا لما آذوه وجفوه ودخل الشعب وأمر أصحابه باعتزالهم والهجرة إلى الحبشة الحديث رواه موسى بن عقبة في المغازي ومن طريقه البيهقي في الدلائل عن ابن شهاب مرسلا رواه ابن سعد في الطبقات من رواية ابن شهاب علي بن أبي بكر بن عبد الرحمن بن الحارث بن هشام مرسلا أيضا ووصله من رواية أبي سلمة الحضرمي عن ابن عباس إلا أن ابن سعد ذكر أن المشركين حصروا بني هاشم في الشعب وذكر موسى بن عقبة أن أبا طالب جمع بني عبد المطلب وأمرهم أن يدخلوا رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم شعبهم ومغازي موسى بن عقبة أصح المغازي وذكر موسى بن عقبة أيضا أنه أمر أصحابه حين دخل الشعب بالخروج إلى أرض الحبشة ولأبي داود من حديث أبي موسى أمرنا النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم أن ننطلق إلى أرض النجاشي قال البيهقي وإسناده صحيح ولأحمد من حديث ابن مسعود بعثنا رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم إلى النجاشي وروى ابن إسحاق بإسناد جيد ومن طريقه البيهقي في الدلائل من حديث أم سلمة إن بأرض الحبشة ملكا لا يظلم أحد عنده فالحقوا ببلاده الحديث ثم تلاحقوا به إلى المدينة بعد أن أعلى الله كلمته وهذا أيضا اعتزال عن الكفار بعد اليأس منهم فإنه صلى الله عليه وسلم لم يعتزل المسلمين ولا من توقع إسلامه من الكفار وأهل الكهف لم يعتزل بعضهم بعضا وهم مؤمنون وإنما اعتزلوا الكفار وإنما النظر في العزلة من المسلمين
O Companions of the Cave [Ashab al-Kahf], and when you have withdrawn from them and what they worship except Allah, then take refuge in the Cave; your Lord will spread for you from His mercy [rahmah]. He commanded them to withdraw [al-'uzlah]. And indeed, our Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, withdrew from Quraysh when they harmed and shunned him, and he entered the Pass [al-Shi'b]. And he commanded his companions to withdraw from them and emigrate to the land of Abyssinia. The narration of his withdrawal, peace and blessings be upon him, from Quraysh when they harmed and shunned him, and he entered the Pass, and he commanded his companions to withdraw from them and emigrate to Abyssinia—this narration was related by Musa ibn 'Uqbah in *al-Maghazi*, and through his chain by al-Bayhaqi in *al-Dala'il*, from Ibn Shihab, as a *mursal* report. Ibn Sa'd related it in *al-Tabaqat* from the narration of Ibn Shihab from 'Ali ibn Abi Bakr ibn 'Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Harith ibn Hisham, also as a *mursal* report. And he connected its chain from the narration of Abu Salamah al-Hadrami from Ibn 'Abbas, except that Ibn Sa'd mentioned that the polytheists besieged Banu Hashim in the Pass. And Musa ibn 'Uqbah mentioned that Abu Talib gathered Banu 'Abd al-Muttalib and commanded them to bring the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, into their pass. And the *Maghazi* of Musa ibn 'Uqbah are the most authentic of the military expeditions. And Musa ibn 'Uqbah also mentioned that he commanded his companions, when he entered the Pass, to depart for the land of Abyssinia. And in Abu Dawud, from the hadith of Abu Musa: "The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded us to set out for the land of the Negus." Al-Bayhaqi said: "Its chain is authentic." And in Ahmad, from the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent us to the Negus." And Ibn Ishaq related with a sound chain, and through his chain al-Bayhaqi in *al-Dala'il*, from the hadith of Umm Salamah: "Indeed, in the land of Abyssinia there is a king under whom no one is wronged. So proceed to his land," the hadith. Then they joined him successively in Medina after Allah had exalted His Word. And this too is a withdrawal from the disbelievers after despairing of them, for he, peace and blessings be upon him, did not withdraw from the Muslims, nor from those among the disbelievers from whom he anticipated Islam. And the People of the Cave [Ashab al-Kahf] did not withdraw from one another, for they were believers. They only withdrew from the disbelievers. The consideration, therefore, is regarding withdrawal from Muslims.

a.g: And [had you been present], you would see the sun when it rose, inclining away from their cave on the right, and when it set, passing away from them on the left, while they were [laying] within an open space thereof. That was from the signs of Allah. He whom Allah guides is the [rightly] guided, but he whom He leaves astray - never will you find for him a protecting guide.

And you would think them awake, while they were asleep. And We turned them to the right and to the left, while their dog stretched his forelegs at the entrance. If you had looked at them, you would have turned from them in flight and been filled by them with terror.

And similarly, We awakened them that they might question one another. Said a speaker from among them, "How long have you remained [here]?" They said, "We have remained a day or part of a day." They said, "Your Lord is most knowing of how long you remained. So send one of you with this silver coin of yours to the city and let him look to which is the best of food and bring you provision from it and let him be cautious. And let no one be aware of you.
Indeed, if they come to know of you, they will stone you or return you to their religion. And never would you succeed, then - ever."

And similarly, We caused them to be found that they [who found them] would know that the promise of Allah is truth and that of the Hour there is no doubt. [That was] when they disputed among themselves about their affair and [then] said, "Construct over them a structure. Their Lord is most knowing about them." Said those who prevailed in the matter, "We will surely take [for ourselves] over them a masjid."

They will say there were three, the fourth of them being their dog; and they will say there were five, the sixth of them being their dog - guessing at the unseen; and they will say there were seven, and the eighth of them was their dog. Say, [O Muhammad], "My Lord is most knowing of their number. None knows them except a few. So do not argue about them except with an obvious argument and do not inquire about them among [the speculators] from anyone."
And never say of anything, "Indeed, I will do that tomorrow,"
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
فقد أدب الله سبحانه نبيه ﭬ فقال تعالى: ﴿ ولا تقولن لشيء إني فاعل ذلك غدا إلا أن يشاء الله ﴾ {} ثم لم يقتصر على ذلك فيما لا يشك فيه بل قال تعالى: ﴿ لتدخلن المسجد الحرام إن شاء الله آمنين محلقين رءؤسكم ومقصرين ﴾ {} وكان الله سبحانه عالما بأنهم يدخلون لا محالة وأنه شاءه ولكن المقصود تعليمه ذلك فتأدب رسول الله ﭬ في ما كان يخبر عنه معلوما كان أو مشكوكا حتى قال ﭬ لما دخل المقابر: (السلام عليكم دار قوم مؤمنين وإنا إن شاء الله بكم لاحقون) واللحوق بهم غير مشكوك فيه ولكن مقتضى الأدب ذكر الله تعالى وربط الأمور به وهذه الصيغة دالة عليه حتى صار بعرف الاستعمال عبارة عن إظهار الرغبة والتمني فإذا قيل لك إن فلانا يموت سريعا فتقول إن شاء الله فيفهم منه رغبتك لا تشككك وإذا قيل لك فلان سيزول مرضه ويصح فتقول إن شاء الله بمعنى الرغبة فقد صارت الكلمة معدولة عن معنى التشكيك إلى معنى الرغبة وكذلك العدول إلى معنى التأدب لذكر الله تعالى كيف كان الأمر.
Indeed, God the Exalted disciplined His Prophet ﷺ, so He said: **"And never say of anything, 'Indeed, I will do that tomorrow,' except [with], 'If God wills [in shā’a Allāh].'"** Then He did not restrict that to matters of doubt, but rather said: **"You will surely enter the Sacred Mosque, if God wills [in shā’a Allāh], secure, with your heads shaved and [hair] shortened."** And God the Exalted knew that they would enter without fail and that He had willed it, but the purpose was to teach him that discipline. So the Messenger of God ﷺ disciplined himself in what he would inform of, whether it was known or doubted, until he ﷺ said when he entered the graveyards: "Peace be upon you, O abode of a believing people, and we, if God wills [in shā’a Allāh], will surely join you." And joining them is not a matter of doubt, but the requirement of discipline [adab] is the mention of God the Exalted and the linking of all matters to Him. And this phrase indicates that, until it became, by customary usage, an expression for showing desire [raghba] and hope [tamannī]. So if it is said to you that so-and-so will die soon, and you say, "If God wills [in shā’a Allāh]," it is understood from it your desire, not your doubt. And if it is said to you that so-and-so's illness will depart and he will recover, and you say, "If God wills [in shā’a Allāh]," with the meaning of desire, then the word has shifted from the meaning of doubt to the meaning of desire. And likewise is the shift to the meaning of discipline [adab] for the mention of God the Exalted, however the matter may be.

a.g: Except [when adding], "If Allah wills." And remember your Lord when you forget [it] and say, "Perhaps my Lord will guide me to what is nearer than this to right conduct."
And they remained in their cave for three hundred years and exceeded by nine.

Say, "Allah is most knowing of how long they remained. He has [knowledge of] the unseen [aspects] of the heavens and the earth. How Seeing is He and how Hearing! They have not besides Him any protector, and He shares not His legislation with anyone."
And recite, [O Muhammad], what has been revealed to you of the Book of your Lord. There is no changer of His words, and never will you find in other than Him a refuge.

And keep yourself patient [by being] with those who call upon their Lord in the morning and the evening, seeking His countenance. And let not your eyes pass beyond them, desiring adornments of the worldly life, and do not obey one whose heart We have made heedless of Our remembrance and who follows his desire and whose affair is ever [in] neglect.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وهم ارفع درجة من الالتفات إلى المنكوح والمطعوم في الجنة فإنهم لم يقصدوها بل هم الذين يدعون ربهم بالغداة والعشي يريدون وجهه فقط وثواب الناس بقدر نياتهم فلا جرم يتنعمون بالنظر إلى وجهه الكريم ويسخرون ممن يلتفت إلى وجه الحور العين كما يسخر المتنعم بالنظر إلى الحور العين ممن يتنعم بالنظر إلى وجه الصور المصنوعة من الطين بل أشد فإن التفاوت بين جمال حضرة الربوبية وجمال الحور العين أشد وأعظم كثيرا من التفاوت بين جمال الحور العين والصور المصنوعة من الطين.
Indeed, they are of a loftier degree than those who turn their attention to spouses and food in Paradise. For they did not seek these things. Rather, they are those who call upon their Lord in the morning and the evening, desiring only His Countenance [wajh]. And the reward of people is according to their intentions [niyyat]. Thus, it is no wonder they delight in gazing upon His Noble Countenance [wajh], and they look with amusement upon one who turns his attention to the faces of the wide-eyed maidens [hur al-'ayn], just as one who delights in gazing upon the wide-eyed maidens looks with amusement upon one who delights in gazing upon the faces of images fashioned from clay. Nay, it is more severe. For the disparity between the beauty of the Presence of Lordship [hudrat al-rububiyya] and the beauty of the wide-eyed maidens is far more severe and greater than the disparity between the beauty of the wide-eyed maidens and images fashioned from clay.

a.g: And say, "The truth is from your Lord, so whoever wills - let him believe; and whoever wills - let him disbelieve." Indeed, We have prepared for the wrongdoers a fire whose walls will surround them. And if they call for relief, they will be relieved with water like murky oil, which scalds [their] faces. Wretched is the drink, and evil is the resting place.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
فإذا دنت من وجوههم شوت وجوههم فإذا دخل الشراب بطونهم قطع ما فى بطونهم فيقولون ادعوا خزنة جهنم قال فيدعون خزنة جهنم أن ادعوا ربكم يخفف عنا يوما من العذاب فيقولون أو لم تك تأتيكم رسلكم بالبينات قالوا بلى قالوا فادعوا وما دعاء الكافرين إلا فى ضلال قال فيقولون ادعوا مالكا فيدعون فيقولون يا مالك ليقض علينا ربك قال فيجيبهم إنكم ماكثون. وقال تعالى: ﴿ وإن يستغيثوا يغاثوا بماء كالمهل يشوى الوجوه ﴾ فهذه طعامهم وشرابهم عند جوعهم وعطشهم.
Indeed, when it draws near to their faces, it scalds their faces, and when it enters their bellies, it cuts what is within their bellies. Then they say, "Call the keepers of Hell [khazanat jahannam]." So they call the keepers of Hell, saying, "Call upon your Lord to lighten for us a day of the punishment." They say, "Did not your messengers come to you with clear proofs?" They say, "Yes." They say, "Then call [upon Him]." But the supplication of the disbelievers is only in error. So they say, "Call Malik." So they call. Then they say, "O Malik, let your Lord finish with us." So he answers them, "Indeed, you will remain." And He, the Exalted, said: "And if they cry for relief, they will be relieved with water like molten brass which scalds the faces." This is their food and their drink in their hunger and their thirst.

a.g: Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds - indeed, We will not allow to be lost the reward of any who did well in deeds.

Those will have gardens of perpetual residence; beneath them rivers will flow. They will be adorned therein with bracelets of gold and will wear green garments of fine silk and brocade, reclining therein on adorned couches. Excellent is the reward, and good is the resting place.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
قال ﭬ فى قوله تعالى: ﴿ يحلون فيها من أساور من ذهب ﴾ {} قال: (إن عليهم التيجان إن أدنى لؤلؤة فيها تضىء ما بين المشرق والمغرب[234])
Indeed, upon them are crowns [tijan]. Indeed, the lowest pearl [lu'lu'a] among them illuminates what is between the East and the West.

a.g: And present to them an example of two men: We granted to one of them two gardens of grapevines, and We bordered them with palm trees and placed between them [fields of] crops.
Each of the two gardens produced its fruit and did not fall short thereof in anything. And We caused to gush forth within them a river.
And he had fruit, so he said to his companion while he was conversing with him, "I am greater than you in wealth and mightier in [numbers of] men."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وكل ذلك جهل منه بفضيلة الفقر وآفة الغنى، وإليه الإشارة بقوله تعالى "فقال لصاحبه وهو يحاوره أنا أكثر منك مالاً وأعز نفراً" حتى أجابه فقال "إن ترني أنا أقل منك مالاً وولداً فعسى ربي أن يؤتيني خيراً من جنتك ويرسل عليها حسباناً من السماء فتصبح صعيداً زلقاً أو يصبح ماؤها غوراً فلن تستطيع له طلباً" وكان ذلك منه تكبراً بالمال والولد، ثم بين الله عاقبة أمره بقوله "يا ليتني لم أشرك بربي أحداً"
Indeed, all of that is ignorance [jahl] from him regarding the virtue of poverty [faqr] and the affliction of wealth [ghina], and to this is the allusion in His saying, the Most High: "So he said to his companion while he was conversing with him, 'I am more than you in wealth and mightier in supporters.'" Until he answered him, saying: "If you see me as less than you in wealth and children, then perhaps my Lord will give me better than your garden and send upon it a reckoning from the sky, so it becomes a barren, slippery ground, or its water becomes sunken, so you will never be able to seek it." And that was from him arrogance [takabbur] through wealth and children. Then Allah made clear the outcome of his affair in His saying: "Oh, would that I had not associated with my Lord anyone."

a.g: And he entered his garden while he was unjust to himself. He said, "I do not think that this will perish - ever.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وذم الله تعالى صاحب البستان إذا دخل جنته وقال: ﴿ ما أظن تبيده هذه أبدا وما أظن الساعة قائمة ولئن رددت إلى ربدى لأجدن خيرا منها منقلبا ﴾{} فإذا العبد المجتهد في الطاعات المجتنب للمعاصى حقيق بإن ينتظر من فضل الله تمام النعمة وما تمام النعمة إلا بدخول الجنة وأما العاصى فإذا تاب وتدارك جميع ما فرط منه من تقصير فحقيق بأن يرجو قبول التوبة وأما قبل التوبة إذا كان كارها للمعصية تسوءه السيئة وتسره الحسنة وهو يذم نفسه ويلومها ويشتهى التوبة ويشتاق إليها فحقيق بأن يرجو منا لله التوفيق للتوبة لأن كراهيتة للمعصية وحؤصه على التوبة يجرى مجرى السبب الذى قد يفضى إلى التوبة وإما الرجاء بعد تأكد الأسباب ولذلك قال تعالى: ﴿ إن الذين آمنوا والذين هاجروا وجاهدوا في سبيل الله أولئك يرجون رحمة الله ﴾ {} معناه أولئك يستحقون أن يرجوا رحمة الله وما أراد به تخصيص وجود الرجاء لأن غيرهم أيضا قد يرجو ولكن خصص بهم استحقاق الرجاء فأما من ينهمك فيما يكرهه الله تعالى ولا يذم نفسه عليه ولا يعزم على التوبة والرجوع فرجاؤه المغفرة حمق كرجاء من بث البذر في أرض سبخة وعزم على أن لا يتعهده بسقى ولا تنقية.
And Allah the Exalted censured the owner of the garden when he entered his garden and said: "I do not think this will ever perish, and I do not think the Hour will occur. And even if I am returned to my Lord, I will surely find better than this as a return." Indeed, the servant who strives in acts of obedience and abstains from sins is worthy of expecting from the bounty of Allah the completion of the blessing, and what is the completion of the blessing except by entering Paradise. As for the sinner, if he repents and recovers all that he has neglected from shortcomings, he is worthy of hoping for the acceptance of repentance. And as for before repentance, if he is averse to the sin—the evil deed displeases him and the good deed pleases him—and he censures himself and blames it, and he desires repentance and yearns for it, then he is worthy of hoping from Allah for the enabling to repent, because his aversion to the sin and his eagerness for repentance runs in the manner of a cause [sabab] which may lead to repentance. As for hope [raja'] after the causes are firmly established, and for that reason Allah the Exalted said: "Indeed, those who have believed and those who have emigrated and striven in the cause of Allah - those hope for the mercy of Allah." Its meaning is: those deserve to hope for the mercy of Allah. He did not intend by it to specify the mere existence of hope, for others may also hope, but He specified them with deserving the hope. As for one who plunges into what Allah the Exalted dislikes and does not censure himself for it, nor resolves upon repentance and return, his hope for forgiveness is foolishness, like the hope of one who scatters seed in barren land and resolves not to tend it with watering or purification.

a.g: And I do not think the Hour will occur. And even if I should be brought back to my Lord, I will surely find better than this as a return."

Tafsir Al-Ihya
وأما غرور الكفار بالله: فمثاله قول بعضهم في أنفسهم وبألسنتهم: إنه لو كان لله من معاد فنحن أحق به من غيرنا ونحن أوفر حظاً فيه وأسعد حالاً، كما أخبر الله تعالى عنه من قول الرجلين المتجاورين إذ قال "وما أظن الساعة قائمة ولئن رددت إلى ربي لأجدن خيراً منها منقلباً" وجملة أمرهما كما نقل في التفسير: أن الكافر منهما بنى قصراً بألف دينار واشترى بستاناً بألف دينار وخدماً بألف دينار وتزوج امرأة على ألف دينار، وفي ذلك كله يعظه المؤمن ويقول: اشتريت قصراً يفنى ويخرب ألا اشتريت قصراً في الجنة لا يفنى! واشتريت بستاناً يخرب ويفنى ألا اشتريت بستاناً في الجنة لا يفنى وخدماً لا يفنون ولا يموتون وزوجة من الحور العين لا تموت! وفي كل ذلك يرد عليه الكافر ويقول: ما هناك شيء وما قيل من ذلك فهو أكاذيب! وإن كان فليكونن لي في الجنة خير من هذا.
Indeed, as for the delusion [ghurur] of the disbelievers concerning Allah: its example is the statement of some of them within themselves and with their tongues: "If there is a return [ma'ad] to Allah, then we are more deserving of it than others, and we have a greater share in it and a happier state," just as Allah the Exalted informed about him from the saying of the two neighboring men when he said, **"And I do not think the Hour will occur. And even if I am returned to my Lord, I will surely find better than this as a final return."** And the entirety of their affair, as related in the interpretation [tafsir], is that the disbeliever of the two built a palace for a thousand dinars, bought an orchard for a thousand dinars, bought servants for a thousand dinars, and married a woman for a thousand dinars. In all of that, the believer admonished him, saying: "You bought a palace that perishes and is ruined—why did you not buy a palace in Paradise that does not perish! And you bought an orchard that is ruined and perishes—why did you not buy an orchard in Paradise that does not perish, and servants who do not perish nor die, and a wife from the wide-eyed maidens [hur al-'ayn] who does not die!" And in all of that, the disbeliever would reply to him, saying: "There is nothing there, and what is said of that is lies! And if it were, then surely what is for me in Paradise would be better than this."

a.g: His companion said to him while he was conversing with him, "Have you disbelieved in He who created you from dust and then from a sperm-drop and then proportioned you [as] a man?
But as for me, He is Allah, my Lord, and I do not associate with my Lord anyone.
And why did you, when you entered your garden, not say, 'What Allah willed [has occurred]; there is no power except in Allah '? Although you see me less than you in wealth and children,

وقال رسول الله ﭬ: (الباقيات الصالحات هن لا إله إلا الله وسبحان الله والحمد لله والله أكبر ولا حول ولا قوة إلا بالله[37]) وقال ﭬ: (ما على الأرض رجل يقول لا إله إلا الله والله أكبر وسبحان الله والحمد لله ولا حول ولا قوة إلا بالله إلا
Indeed, the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The enduring good deeds [al-baqiyat al-salihat] are: 'There is no god but God [la ilaha illa Allah],' and 'Glory be to God [subhan Allah],' and 'Praise be to God [al-hamdulillah],' and 'God is the Greatest [Allahu Akbar],' and 'There is no power and no strength except by God [la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah].'" And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is no man on the earth who says, 'There is no god but God [la ilaha illa Allah],' and 'God is the Greatest [Allahu Akbar],' and 'Glory be to God [subhan Allah],' and 'Praise be to God [al-hamdulillah],' and 'There is no power and no strength except by God [la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah],' except..."

a.g: It may be that my Lord will give me [something] better than your garden and will send upon it a calamity from the sky, and it will become a smooth, dusty ground,
Or its water will become sunken [into the earth], so you would never be able to seek it."

And his fruits were encompassed [by ruin], so he began to turn his hands about [in dismay] over what he had spent on it, while it had collapsed upon its trellises, and said, "Oh, I wish I had not associated with my Lord anyone."
And there was for him no company to aid him other than Allah, nor could he defend himself.
There the authority is [completely] for Allah, the Truth. He is best in reward and best in outcome.

And present to them the example of the life of this world, [its being] like rain which We send down from the sky, and the vegetation of the earth mingles with it and [then] it becomes dry remnants, scattered by the winds. And Allah is ever, over all things, Perfect in Ability.

Tafsir Al-Ihya
ولما استطار مكر الشيطان في كافة الخلق ارسل الله الملائكة الى الرسل وأوحوا إليهم ما تم على الخلق من اهلاك العدو واغوائه فاشتغلوا بدعوة الخلق الى الملك الحقيقي عن الملك المجازي الذي لا اصل له ان سلم ولا دوام له اصلا فنادوا فيهم ﴿ يا ايها الذين امنوا ما لكم اذا قيل لكم انفروا في سبيل الله اثاقلتم الى الارض أرضيتم بالحياة الدنيا من الاخرة فما متاع الحياة الدنيا في الاخرة الا قليل ﴾ {} فالتوراة والانجيل والزبور والفرقان وصحف موسى وابراهيم وكل كتاب منزل ما أنزل إلالدعوة الخلق الى الملك الدائم المخلد والمراد منهم ان يكونوا ملوكا في الدنيا ملوكا في الآخرة اما ملك الدنيا فالزهد فيها والقناعة باليسير منها واما ملك الآخرة فبالقرب من الله تعالى يدرك بقاء لا فناء فيه وعزا لا ذل فيه وقرة عين اخفيت في هذا العالم لا تعلمها نفس من النفوس والشيطان يدعوهم الى ملك الدنيا لعلمه بان ملك الاخرة يفوت به اذ الدنيا والاخرة ضرتان ولعلمه بأن الدنيا لا تسلم له ايضا ولو كانت تسلم له لكان يحسده ايضا ولكن ملك الدنيا لا يخلو عن المنازعات والمكدرات وطول الهموم في التدبيرات وكذا سائر اسباب الجاه ثم مهما تسلم وتتم الاسباب ينقضي العمر ﴿ حتى اذا اخذت الارض زخرفها وازينت وظن اهلها انهم قادرون عليها اتاها امرنا ليلا او نهارا فجعلناها حصيدا كأن لم تغن بالأمس ﴾ {} فضرب الله تعالى لها مثلا فقال تعالى: ﴿ واضرب لهم مثل الحياة الدنيا كماء انزلناه من السماء فاختلط به نبات الأرض فأصبح هشيما تذروه الرياح ﴾ {} والزهد في الدنيا لما ان كان ملكا حاضرا حسده الشيطان عليه فصده عنه ومعنى الزهد ان يملك العبد شهوته وغضبه فينقادان لباعث الدين واشارة الايمان وهذا ملك بالاستحقاق اذ به يصير صاحبه حرا وباستيلاء الشهوة عليه يصير عبدا لفرجه وبطنه وسائر اغراضه فيكون مسخرا مثل البهيمة مملوكا يستجره زمام الشهوة آخذا بمختنقه الى حيث يريد ويهوى فما اعظم اغترار الانسان اذ ظن انه ينال الملك بأنه يصير مملوكا وينال الربوبية بان يصير عبدا ومثل هذا هل يكون الا معكوسا في الدنيا منكوسا في الآخره ولهذا قال بعض الملوك لبعض الزهاد هل من حاجة؟ قال: كيف اطلب منك حاجة وملكي اعظم من ملكك فقال كيف قال من انت عبده فهو عبد لي فقال كيف ذلك قال انت عبد شهوتك وغضبك وفرجك وبطنك وقد ملكت هؤلاء كلهم فهم عبيد لي فهذا اذن هو الملك في الدنيا وهو الذي يسوق الى الملك في الاخرة فالمخدوعون بغرور الشيطان خسروا الدنيا والآخره جميعا والذين وفقوا للاشتداد على الصراط المستقيم فازوا بالدنيا والاخرة جميعا فإذا عرفت الان معنى الملك والربوبية ومعنى التسخير والعبودية ومدخل الغلط في ذلك وكيفية تعمية الشيطان وتلبيسة يسهل عليك النزوع عن الملك والجاه والإعراض عنه والصبر عند فواته اذ تصير بتركه ملكا في الحال وترجو به ملكا في الآخرة.
Indeed, when the cunning [makr] of Satan spread among all creation, Allah sent the angels to the messengers and they revealed to them what had befallen creation from the destruction and misguidance of the enemy. So they busied themselves with calling creation to the True Kingdom [al-mulk al-haqiqi] over the metaphorical kingdom [al-mulk al-majazi] which has no reality if it is safe, and no permanence at all. So they called out among them: **"O you who have believed, what is [the matter] with you that when you are told to go forth in the cause of Allah you cling heavily to the earth? Are you satisfied with the life of this world [al-hayat al-dunya] rather than the Hereafter [al-akhirah]? But what is the enjoyment of worldly life compared to the Hereafter except a little."** (18:45) Thus, the Torah, the Gospel, the Psalms, the Criterion [al-Furqan], the Scrolls of Moses and Abraham, and every revealed Book was sent for nothing but to call creation to the Everlasting, Eternal Kingdom. And what is intended for them is that they be kings in this world [al-dunya] and kings in the Hereafter [al-akhirah]. As for kingship in this world, it is through asceticism [zuhd] in it and contentment with the little of it. And as for kingship in the Hereafter, it is through proximity to Allah, the Exalted, attained by an everlasting life [baqa'] in which there is no annihilation, and a might ['izz] in which there is no humiliation, and a coolness of the eye [qurrat 'ayn] concealed in this world which no soul [nafs] among souls knows. And Satan calls them to kingship in this world, knowing that the kingship of the Hereafter is lost by it, for this world and the Hereafter are co-wives. And knowing that this world will not be safe for him either, for even if it were safe for him, he would envy it also. But kingship in this world is not free from disputes, disturbances, the length of anxieties in management, and likewise all the causes of status [jah]. Then, however much one secures it and the causes are perfected, the lifespan ends: **"Until, when the earth has taken on its ornaments and is adorned and its people think that they have complete power over it, Our command comes to it by night or by day, and We make it as a harvest, as if it had not flourished the day before."** (10:24) So Allah, the Exalted, struck a parable for it, saying, the Exalted: **"And present to them the example of the life of this world as [like] water which We send down from the sky, and the vegetation of the earth mingles with it and [then] it becomes dry remnants, scattered by the winds."** (18:45) And asceticism [zuhd] in this world, since it is a present kingship, Satan envied it and turned them away from it. And the meaning of asceticism is that the servant [al-'abd] masters his passion [shahwah] and his anger [ghadab], so they become subservient to the motive of religion [din] and the indication of faith [iman]. This is a kingship by right [istihqaq], for by it its possessor becomes free, and by the domination of passion over him he becomes a slave to his private parts, his stomach, and all his other desires, thus being driven like a beast, owned, with the reins of passion pulling him, taking him by his throat to where it wills and desires. So how great is the deception [ghurur] of man when he thinks he attains kingship by becoming owned, and attains lordship [rububiyyah] by becoming a slave! Can such a thing be except inverted in this world and overturned in the Hereafter? For this reason, a certain king said to a certain ascetic: "Do you have a need?" He said: "How can I ask you for a need when my kingdom is greater than your kingdom?" He said: "How?" He said: "Whoever you are a slave to is my slave." He said: "How is that?" He said: "You are a slave to your passion, your anger, your private parts, and your stomach, and I have mastered all of these, so they are my slaves." This, then, is the kingship in this world, and it is what leads to kingship in the Hereafter. So those deceived by the delusion [ghurur] of Satan have lost this world and the Hereafter together. And those who were granted success in holding fast to the Straight Path have won this world and the Hereafter together. So if you now know the meaning of kingship and lordship, and the meaning of subjugation and servitude ['ubudiyyah], and the point of error in that, and the manner of Satan's blinding and his deception, it will become easy for you to turn away from kingship and status, and to turn your back upon it, and to be patient when it is lost, for by abandoning it you become a king in the present, and by it you hope for a kingdom in the Hereafter.

a.g: Wealth and children are [but] adornment of the worldly life. But the enduring good deeds are better to your Lord for reward and better for [one's] hope.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
[37] حديث الباقيات الصالحات هن لا إله إلا الله وسبحان الله والله أكبر والحمد لله ولا حول ولا قوة إلا بالله أخرجه النسائي في اليوم والليلة وابن حبان والحاكم وصححه من حديث أبي سعيد والنسائي والحاكم من حديث أبي هريرة دون قوله ولا حول ولا قوة إلا بالله.
Indeed, they are those who did not understand His saying, the Most High: "Wealth and children are the adornment of the life of this world [zīnat al-ḥayāt al-dunyā], but the enduring good deeds [al-bāqiyāt al-ṣāliḥāt] are better with your Lord for reward and better for hope." For knowledge [al-'ilm] and freedom [al-ḥurriyya] are the enduring good deeds [al-bāqiyāt al-ṣāliḥāt] which remain as a perfection [kamāl] in the soul [al-nafs], and wealth and status are that which perishes in proximity. Indeed, repelling the effects of desire [al-shahwa] and anger [al-ghaḍab] from the soul [al-nafs] is from the perfection [kamāl] which is from the attributes of the angels. Therefore, the perfections [al-kamālāt] are three—if we count 'the absence of being changed by desires and the absence of being subjugated to them' as a perfection [kamāl] like the perfection of knowledge [kamāl al-'ilm] and the perfection of freedom [kamāl al-ḥurriyya]; and I mean by it the absence of servitude to desires and the will for worldly causes—and the perfection of power [kamāl al-qudra] for the servant is a path to acquiring the perfection of knowledge [kamāl al-'ilm] and the perfection of freedom [kamāl al-ḥurriyya]. And there is no path for him to acquiring the perfection of power [kamāl al-qudra] that endures after his death, for indeed his power over the essences of wealth and over the subjugation of hearts [qulūb] and bodies is severed by death, while his knowledge [ma'rifa] and his freedom [ḥurriyya] are not nullified by death. Rather, they remain as a perfection [kamāl] within him and a means to proximity to God, the Most High. So observe how the ignorant ones have turned and have fallen upon their faces, the falling of the blind, so they turned to seeking the perfection of power [kamāl al-qudra] through status and wealth, which is the perfection [kamāl] that does not remain safe, and if it remains safe, it has no permanence. And they turned away from the perfection of freedom [kamāl al-ḥurriyya] and knowledge [kamāl al-'ilm] which, when attained, is eternal, having no severance. And these are they who did not understand His saying, the Most High: "Wealth and children are the adornment of the life of this world [zīnat al-ḥayāt al-dunyā], but the enduring good deeds [al-bāqiyāt al-ṣāliḥāt] are better with your Lord for reward and better for hope." For knowledge [al-'ilm] and freedom [al-ḥurriyya] are the enduring good deeds [al-bāqiyāt al-ṣāliḥāt] which remain as a perfection [kamāl] in the soul [al-nafs], and wealth and status are that which perishes in proximity.

a.g: And [warn of] the Day when We will remove the mountains and you will see the earth prominent, and We will gather them and not leave behind from them anyone.

And they will be presented before your Lord in rows, [and He will say], "You have certainly come to Us just as We created you the first time. But you claimed that We would never make for you an appointment."

And the record [of deeds] will be placed [open], and you will see the criminals fearful of that within it, and they will say, "Oh, woe to us! What is this book that leaves nothing small or great except that it has enumerated it?" And they will find what they did present [before them]. And your Lord does injustice to no one.

And He, the Exalted, said: "And the Record [al-Kitab] will be placed, and you will see the criminals fearful of what is in it, and they will say, 'Woe to us! What is this Record that leaves nothing small or great but that it has enumerated it?' And they will find what they did present [before them]. And your Lord does wrong to no one." So the possessors of insight [arbab al-basa'ir] from among the servants came to know that God, the Exalted, lies in wait for them, and that they will be questioned in the Reckoning [al-Hisab] and will be held accountable for the weight of an atom [mithqal al-dharr] of passing thoughts [al-khatarat] and glances [al-lahzat]. And they realized that nothing will save them from these perils except adhering to self-reckoning [muhasaba] and sincerity in self-observation [muraqaba] and holding the soul [al-nafs] to account for every breath [al-anfas] and movement [al-harakat], and reckoning with it for every passing thought [al-khatarat] and glance [al-lahzat]. For whoever holds his soul [nafs] to account before he is held to account, his reckoning [hisab] on the Day of Resurrection [al-Qiyamah] will be light, his answer will be present when questioned, and his return and outcome will be good. And whoever does not hold his soul [nafs] to account, his regrets will be prolonged, and his standings in the plains of Resurrection [al-Qiyamah] will be lengthy, and his misdeeds [sayyi'at] will lead him to disgrace and contempt. So when this was unveiled to them, they knew that nothing would save them from it except obedience to God. And He had commanded them to patience [al-sabr] and vigilant guarding [al-murabata], so He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "O you who have believed, be patient and endure and guard [wa rabitu]." So they began by guarding their souls [anfus] first: with the mutual stipulation [al-musharata], then with self-observation [al-muraqaba], then with self-reckoning [al-muhasaba], then with self-punishment [al-mu'aqaba], then with striving [al-mujahada], then with self-admonition [al-mu'ataba]. Thus, for them in vigilant guarding [al-murabata] were six stations [maqamat]. And it is necessary to explain them, clarify their reality and virtue, and detail the works within them. And the foundation of that is self-reckoning [al-muhasaba]. But every reckoning [hisab] is after a mutual stipulation [musharata] and self-observation [muraqaba], and is followed, in case of loss, by self-admonition [mu'ataba] and self-punishment [mu'aqaba].

a.g: And [mention] when We said to the angels, "Prostrate to Adam," and they prostrated, except for Iblees. He was of the jinn and departed from the command of his Lord. Then will you take him and his descendants as allies other than Me while they are enemies to you? Wretched it is for the wrongdoers as an exchange.
I did not make them witness to the creation of the heavens and the earth or to the creation of themselves, and I would not have taken the misguiders as assistants.
And [warn of] the Day when He will say, "Call 'My partners' whom you claimed," and they will invoke them, but they will not respond to them. And We will put between them [a valley of] destruction.
And the criminals will see the Fire and will be certain that they are to fall therein. And they will not find from it a way elsewhere.
And We have certainly diversified in this Qur'an for the people from every [kind of] example; but man has ever been, most of anything, [prone to] dispute.

And nothing has prevented the people from believing when guidance came to them and from asking forgiveness of their Lord except that there [must] befall them the [accustomed] precedent of the former peoples or that the punishment should come [directly] before them.

And We send not the messengers except as bringers of good tidings and warners. And those who disbelieve dispute by [using] falsehood to [attempt to] invalidate thereby the truth and have taken My verses, and that of which they are warned, in ridicule.

And who is more unjust than one who is reminded of the verses of his Lord but turns away from them and forgets what his hands have put forth? Indeed, We have placed over their hearts coverings, lest they understand it, and in their ears deafness. And if you invite them to guidance - they will never be guided, then - ever.

And your Lord is the Forgiving, full of mercy. If He were to impose blame upon them for what they earned, He would have hastened for them the punishment. Rather, for them is an appointment from which they will never find an escape.
And those cities - We destroyed them when they wronged, and We made for their destruction an appointed time.
And [mention] when Moses said to his servant, "I will not cease [traveling] until I reach the junction of the two seas or continue for a long period."
But when they reached the junction between them, they forgot their fish, and it took its course into the sea, slipping away.
So when they had passed beyond it, [Moses] said to his boy, "Bring us our morning meal. We have certainly suffered in this, our journey, [much] fatigue."

He said, "Did you see when we retired to the rock? Indeed, I forgot [there] the fish. And none made me forget it except Satan - that I should mention it. And it took its course into the sea amazingly".
[Moses] said, "That is what we were seeking." So they returned, following their footprints.
And they found a servant from among Our servants to whom we had given mercy from us and had taught him from Us a [certain] knowledge.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وإليه الإشارة بقوله تعالى وعلمناه من لدنا علما مع أن كل علم من لدنه ولكن بعضها بوسائط تعليم الخلق فلا يسمى ذلك علما لدنيا بل اللدني الذي ينفتح في سر القلب من غير سبب مألوف من خارج
Indeed, to this is the allusion in His, the Exalted's, saying: "And We taught him from Our Presence a knowledge [‘ilman laduniyyan]." And this is so even though all knowledge is from His Presence, but some of it is through intermediaries of created instruction, so that is not called a knowledge from the Presence [‘ilmun laduniyy]. Rather, the knowledge from the Presence [al-laduniyy] is that which opens up within the secret of the heart [sirr al-qalb] without a customary cause from the outside.

a.g: Moses said to him, "May I follow you on [the condition] that you teach me from what you have been taught of sound judgement?"
He said, "Indeed, with me you will never be able to have patience.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وقد نبه الله تعالى بقصة الخضر وموسى عليهما السلام حيث قال الخضر: (إنك لن تستطيع معي صبرا وكيف تصبر على ما لم تحط به خبرا( (الكهف: 67 و68). ثم شرط عليه السكوت والتسليم فقال: (فإن اتبعتني فلا تسألني عن شيء حتى أحدث لك منه ذكرا( (الكهف: 70). ثم لم يصبر ولم يزل في مراودته إلى أن كان ذلك سبب الفراق بينهما وبالجملة كل متعلم استبقى لنفسه رأيا واختيارا دون اختيار المعلم فاحكم عليه بالإخفاق والخسران.
Indeed, God the Exalted has alerted us through the story of Al-Khidr and Moses, peace be upon them both, where Al-Khidr said: "Indeed, you will not be able to have patience [sabr] with me. And how can you have patience [tasbir] over that of which you have not been given any knowledge [khabr]?" (Al-Kahf: 67-68). Then he stipulated upon him silence and submission [taslim], saying: "Then if you follow me, do not ask me about anything until I myself mention it to you." (Al-Kahf: 70). Yet he did not have patience [yasbir], and he did not cease in his repeated questioning until that became the cause of separation between them. And in summary: every student [muta'allim] who retains for himself an opinion [ra'y] and a choice [ikhtiyar] other than the choice of the teacher [mu'allim], then judge him to be in failure [ikhfaq] and loss [khusran].

a.g: And how can you have patience for what you do not encompass in knowledge?"
[Moses] said, "You will find me, if Allah wills, patient, and I will not disobey you in [any] order."
He said, "Then if you follow me, do not ask me about anything until I make to you about it mention."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
ومنها المبهم وهو اللفظ المشترك بين معن من كلمة أو حرف أما الكلمة فكالشيء والقرين والأمة والروح ونظائرها قال الله تعالى ﴿ فإن اتبعتني فلا تسألني عن شيء ﴾ {} أراد به من صفات الربوبية وهو العلوم التي لا يحل السؤال عنها حتى يبتدئ بها العارف في أوان الاستحقاق
Indeed, from among them is the ambiguous [al-mubham], which is the expression shared between a meaning from a word or a letter. As for the word, such as 'the thing' [al-shay'], 'the companion' [al-qarīn], 'the community' [al-ummah], 'the spirit' [al-rūḥ], and their like. Allah, the Exalted, said: "Then if you follow me, do not ask me about anything [shay']" (18:70). He intended by it from the attributes of Lordship [rubūbiyyah], and they are the knowledges [al-‘ulūm] which it is not permissible to ask about until the knower [al-‘ārif] is initiated with them at the time of deserving [istiḥqāq].

a.g: So they set out, until when they had embarked on the ship, al-Khidh r tore it open. [Moses] said, "Have you torn it open to drown its people? You have certainly done a grave thing."
[Al-Khidh r] said, "Did I not say that with me you would never be able to have patience?"
[Moses] said, "Do not blame me for what I forgot and do not cover me in my matter with difficulty."
So they set out, until when they met a boy, al-Khidh r killed him. [Moses] said, "Have you killed a pure soul for other than [having killed] a soul? You have certainly done a deplorable thing."
[Al-Khidh r] said, "Did I not tell you that with me you would never be able to have patience?"
[Moses] said, "If I should ask you about anything after this, then do not keep me as a companion. You have obtained from me an excuse."

So they set out, until when they came to the people of a town, they asked its people for food, but they refused to offer them hospitality. And they found therein a wall about to collapse, so al-Khidh r restored it. [Moses] said, "If you wished, you could have taken for it a payment."
[Al-Khidh r] said, "This is parting between me and you. I will inform you of the interpretation of that about which you could not have patience.
As for the ship, it belonged to poor people working at sea. So I intended to cause defect in it as there was after them a king who seized every [good] ship by force.
And as for the boy, his parents were believers, and we feared that he would overburden them by transgression and disbelief.
So we intended that their Lord should substitute for them one better than him in purity and nearer to mercy.

And as for the wall, it belonged to two orphan boys in the city, and there was beneath it a treasure for them, and their father had been righteous. So your Lord intended that they reach maturity and extract their treasure, as a mercy from your Lord. And I did it not of my own accord. That is the interpretation of that about which you could not have patience."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
اعلم أن الله تعالى قد سمى المال خيراً في مواضع من كتابه العزيز فقل جل وعز "إن ترك خيراً" الآية وقال رسول الله ﭬ "نعم المال الصالح للرجل الصالح" وكل ما جاء في ثواب الصدقة والحج فهو ثناء على المال إذ لا يمكن الوصول إليهما إلا به. ولا تقف على وجه الجمع بعد الذم والمدح إلا بأن تعرف حكمة المال ومقصوده وآفاته وغوائله؛ حتى ينكشف لك أنه خير من وجه وشر من وجه، وأنه محمود من حيث هو خير ومذموم من حيث هو شر، فإنه ليس بخير محض ولا شر محض، بل هو سبب للأمرين جميعاً وما هذا وصفه فيمدح لا محالة تارة ويذم أخرى، ولكن البصير المميز يدرك أن المحمود منه غير المذموم، وبيانه بالاستمداد مما ذكرناه في كتاب الشكر من بيان الخيرات وتفصيل درجات النعم، والقدر المقنع فيه هو أن مقصد الأكياس وأرباب البصائر سعادة الآخرة التي هي النعيم الدائم والملك والمقيم. والقصد إلى هذا دأب الكرام والأكياس، إذ قيل لرسول الله ﭬ: من أكرم الناس وأكيسهم؟ فقال "أكثرهم للموت ذكراً وأشدهم له استعداداً" وهذه السعادة لا تنال إلا بثلاث وسائل في الدنيا وهي الفضائل النفسية، كالعلم وحسن الخلق، والفضائل البدنية: كالصحة والسلامة، والفضائل الخارجة عن البدن: كالمال وسائر الأسباب. وأعلاها النفسية، ثم البدنية، ثم الخارجة. فالخارجة أخسها والمال من جملة الخارجات، وأدناها الدراهم والدنانير، فإنهما خادمان ولا خادم لهما، ومرادان لغيرهما. ولا يرادان لذاتهما؛ إذ النفس هي الجوهر النفيس المطلوب سعادتها، وأنها تخدم العلم والمعرفة ومكارم الأخلاق لتحصلها صفة في ذاتها، والبدن يخدم النفس بواسطة الحواس والأعضاء، والمطاعم والملابس تخدم البدن. وقد سبق أن المقصود من المطاعم إبقاء البدن. ومن المناكح إبقاء النسل، ومن البدن تكميل النفس وتزكيتها وتزيينها بالعلم والأخلاق. ومن عرف هذا الترتيب فقد عرف قدر المال ووجه شرفه، وأنه من حيث هو ضرورة المطاعم والملابس التي هي ضرورة بقاء البدن الذي هو ضرورة كمال النفس الذي هو خير ومن عرف فائدة الشيء وغايته ومقصده واستعمله لتلك الغاية ملتفتاً إليها غير ناس لها فقد أحسن وانتفع، وكان ما حصل له الغرض محموداً في حقه، فإذا المال آلة ووسيلة. زرتهم فرأيت فيهم سيما الخير وآثار الفضل فقلت بلغ أثره في الخير إليهم وظهرت بركته فيهم مستدلاً بقوله تعالى "وكان أبوهما صالحاً"
Know that God the Exalted has named wealth [al-mal] as a good [khayr] in places within His Mighty Book. He, Glorified and Exalted, said: "If he leaves good [khayr]..." and His Messenger, peace be upon him, said: "How excellent is righteous wealth [al-mal al-salih] for a righteous man." And all that has come regarding the reward for charity and Hajj is praise for wealth [al-mal], for reaching them is not possible except through it. You will not grasp the manner of reconciliation after its censure and praise except by knowing the wisdom [hikma] of wealth [al-mal], its purpose [maqsud], its corruptions [afat], and its perils [ghawa'il]; until it is unveiled to you that it is good [khayr] from one aspect and evil [sharr] from another, and that it is praiseworthy [mahmud] inasmuch as it is good [khayr] and blameworthy [madhmum] inasmuch as it is evil [sharr]. For it is not pure good [khayr mahd] nor pure evil [sharr mahd], but rather it is a cause [sabab] for both matters together. That which has this description is inevitably praised [yumdah] at one time and censured [yudham] at another. However, the discerning, distinguishing one [al-basir al-mumayyiz] perceives that the praiseworthy [al-mahmud] from it is other than the blameworthy [al-madhmum]. Its clarification is by seeking aid from what We mentioned in the Book of Gratitude [Kitab al-Shukr] regarding the clarification of goods [khayrat] and the detailing of the degrees of blessings [ni'am]. The sufficient measure [al-qadr al-muqni'] in this is that the purpose [maqsud] of the intelligent [al-akkiya'] and the possessors of insight [arbab al-basa'ir] is the happiness [sa'ada] of the Hereafter [al-akhira], which is the everlasting bliss [al-na'im al-da'im] and the permanent, abiding dominion. Striving for this is the constant practice of the noble and the intelligent [al-akkiya']. For it was said to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him: "Who are the most honorable and most intelligent of people?" He said: "Those who remember death the most and are the most prepared for it." This happiness [sa'ada] is not attained except by three means [wasai'il] in the world [al-dunya]: they are the spiritual virtues [al-fada'il al-nafsiyya], such as knowledge [al-'ilm] and good character [husn al-khuluq]; the bodily virtues [al-fada'il al-badaniyya], such as health [al-sihha] and safety [al-salamah]; and the virtues external to the body [al-fada'il al-kharija 'an al-badan], such as wealth [al-mal] and all other means [al-asbab]. The highest of them are the spiritual [al-nafsiyya], then the bodily [al-badaniyya], then the external [al-kharija]. The external [al-kharija] is the basest of them, and wealth [al-mal] is among the external ones [al-kharijat]. The lowest of them are dirhams and dinars, for they are servants [khadiman] and have no servant [la khadim lahum], and they are intended for other than themselves [muradan li-ghayrihim]. They are not desired for their own selves [la yuradu li-dhatihim]; for the soul [al-nafs] is the precious substance [al-jawhar al-nafis] whose happiness [sa'adatuhu] is sought, and it serves knowledge [al-'ilm] and gnosis [al-ma'rifa] and noble character traits [makrim al-akhlaq] to acquire them as attributes in its essence [dhat]. The body [al-badan] serves the soul [al-nafs] by means of the senses [al-hawas] and limbs [al-a'da']. Food and drink [al-mata'im] and garments [al-malabis] serve the body [al-badan]. It has preceded that the purpose [al-maqsud] from food and drink [al-mata'im] is the preservation of the body [ibqa' al-badan]. And from marriage [al-munakah] is the preservation of progeny [ibqa' al-nasl]. And from the body [al-badan] is the perfection [takmil] of the soul [al-nafs], its purification [tazkiya], and its adornment [tazyin] with knowledge [al-'ilm] and character [al-akhlaq]. Whoever knows this order [al-tartib] has known the rank [qadr] of wealth [al-mal] and the aspect of its nobility [wajh sharafih], and that it is, inasmuch as it is a necessity [darura] for food and drink [al-mata'im] and garments [al-malabis]—which are a necessity [darura] for the survival of the body [baqa' al-badan]—which is a necessity [darura] for the perfection [kamal] of the soul [al-nafs]—which is a good [khayr]—[then it is good]. Whoever knows the benefit [fa'ida] of a thing, its ultimate end [ghaya], and its purpose [maqsud], and uses it for that ultimate end [ghaya], attentive to it, not forgetful of it, has done well and benefited. That which he obtained for the purpose [al-gharad] becomes praiseworthy [mahmud] in his regard. Therefore, wealth [al-mal] is a tool [ala] and a means [wasila]. I visited them and saw in them the marks [sima] of good [al-khayr] and the traces [athar] of virtue [al-fadl]. So I said: Its effect [athar] in good [al-khayr] has reached them and its blessing [baraka] has become manifest in them, inferring from His saying, the Exalted: "And their father was righteous [salih]."

a.g: And they ask you, [O Muhammad], about Dhul-Qarnayn. Say, "I will recite to you about him a report."
Indeed We established him upon the earth, and We gave him to everything a way.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وما هو قادر عليه من نفسه وغيره فليست قدرته من نفسه وبنفسه بل الله خالقه وخالق قدرته وخالق أسبابه والممكن له من ذلك. ولو سلط بعوضاً على أعظم ملك وأقوى شخص من الحيوانات لأهلكه، فليس للعبد قدرة إلا بتمكين مولاه كما قال في أعظم ملوك الأرض ذي القرنين إذ قال " إنا مكنا له في الأرض " فلم يكن جميع ملكه وسلطنته إلا بتمكين الله تعالى إياه في جزء من الأرض، والأرض كلها مدرة بالإضافة إلى أجسام العالم وجميع الولايات التي يحظى بها الناس من الأرض غبرة من تلك المدرة، ثم تلك الغبرة أيضاً من فضل الله تعالى وتمكينه.
Indeed, what he is capable of, from himself and from others, is not a capability [qudra] from himself and by himself. Rather, Allah is his Creator [Khaliq], and the Creator of his capability, and the Creator of its causes, and the One who makes it possible for him. And if He were to empower a mosquito over the greatest king and the strongest of animals, it would destroy him. So the servant ['abd] has no capability except through the enabling [tamkin] of his Master [Mawla], as He said regarding the greatest king of the earth, Dhul-Qarnayn, when He said: "Indeed, We enabled him in the earth." Thus, all of his dominion and sovereignty was only through the enabling of him by Allah, the Exalted, in a portion of the earth. And the entire earth is but a speck of dust [mudra] in comparison to the bodies of the world ['alam]. And all the authorities [wilayat] that people possess from the earth are but a mote [ghubra] from that speck of dust. Then, that mote is also from the bounty [fadl] of Allah, the Exalted, and His enabling.

a.g: So he followed a way

Until, when he reached the setting of the sun, he found it [as if] setting in a spring of dark mud, and he found near it a people. Allah said, "O Dhul-Qarnayn, either you punish [them] or else adopt among them [a way of] goodness."
He said, "As for one who wrongs, we will punish him. Then he will be returned to his Lord, and He will punish him with a terrible punishment.
But as for one who believes and does righteousness, he will have a reward of Paradise, and we will speak to him from our command with ease."
Then he followed a way
Until, when he came to the rising of the sun, he found it rising on a people for whom We had not made against it any shield.
Thus. And We had encompassed [all] that he had in knowledge.
Then he followed a way
Until, when he reached [a pass] between two mountains, he found beside them a people who could hardly understand [his] speech.
They said, "O Dhul-Qarnayn, indeed Gog and Magog are [great] corrupters in the land. So may we assign for you an expenditure that you might make between us and them a barrier?"
He said, "That in which my Lord has established me is better [than what you offer], but assist me with strength; I will make between you and them a dam.

Bring me sheets of iron" - until, when he had leveled [them] between the two mountain walls, he said, "Blow [with bellows]," until when he had made it [like] fire, he said, "Bring me, that I may pour over it molten copper."
So Gog and Magog were unable to pass over it, nor were they able [to effect] in it any penetration.
[Dhul-Qarnayn] said, "This is a mercy from my Lord; but when the promise of my Lord comes, He will make it level, and ever is the promise of my Lord true."
And We will leave them that day surging over each other, and [then] the Horn will be blown, and We will assemble them in [one] assembly.
And We will present Hell that Day to the Disbelievers, on display -
Those whose eyes had been within a cover [removed] from My remembrance, and they were not able to hear.
Then do those who disbelieve think that they can take My servants instead of Me as allies? Indeed, We have prepared Hell for the disbelievers as a lodging.
Say, [O Muhammad], "Shall we [believers] inform you of the greatest losers as to [their] deeds?
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وكم من أعمال يتعب الإنسان فيها ويظن أنها خالصة لوجه الله ويكون فيها مغرور لأنه لا يرى وجه الآفة فيها كما حكى عن بعضهم أنه قال قضيت صلاة ثلاثين سنة كنت صليتها في المسجد في الصف الأول لأنى تأخرت يوما لعذر فصليت في الصف الثانى فاعترتني خجلة من الناس حيث رأونى في الصف الثانى فعرفت أن نظر الناس إلى في الصف الأول كان مسرتى وسبب استراحة قلبى من حيث لا أشعر وهذا دقيق غامض قلما تسلم الأعمال من أمثاله وقل من يتنبه له إلا من وفقه الله تعالى والغافلون يرون حسناتهم كلها في الآخرة سيئات وهم المرادون بقوله تعالى (وبدا لهم من الله مالم يكونوا يحتسبون وبدا لهم سيئات ما كسبوا) وبقوله تعالى (قل هل ننبئكم بالأخسرين أعمالا الذين ضل سعيهم في الحياة الدنيا وهم يحسبون أنهم يحسنون صنعا.)
Indeed, by His saying, the Most High: "Say, 'Shall We inform you of the greatest losers in respect of their works? Those whose effort is lost in worldly life, while they think that they are doing well in work.'" And how many are the works in which a person toils and believes they are purely for the Face of God [li-wajhi Allah], yet he is therein deluded because he does not see the aspect of the affliction [al-afah] within it. As it is narrated from one of them that he said: "I completed a prayer of thirty years which I had prayed in the mosque in the first row, because one day I was delayed for a reason and prayed in the second row. A sense of shame from the people overcame me when they saw me in the second row, so I knew that the people's gaze upon me in the first row had been my joy and the cause of my heart's [qalb] comfort from where I was unaware." And this is subtle, obscure; rarely are deeds safe from its like, and few are those who are alerted to it except whom God, the Most High, has granted success. And the heedless see all their good deeds [hasanat] as bad deeds [sayyi'at] in the Hereafter [al-Akhirah], and they are the ones intended by His saying, the Most High: "Say, 'Shall We inform you of the greatest losers in respect of their works? Those whose effort is lost in worldly life, while they think that they are doing well in work.'" And the most exposed of creation to this trial [fitnah] are the scholars [al-'ulama']. For the motive for most of them in spreading knowledge [al-'ilm] is the pleasure of mastery, the joy of being followed, and the gladness at praise and commendation. And Satan [al-Shaytan] makes that seem fair to them and says: "Your aim is to spread the religion of God and to strive for the Sacred Law [al-Shar'] which His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, legislated." And you see the preacher holding it as a favor upon God, the Most High, that he advises the creation and admonishes the rulers, and he rejoices at the people's acceptance of his words and their turning to him, while he claims that he rejoices at what has been made easy for him of supporting the religion. And if one of his peers appeared who was better than him in admonition, and the people turned away from him and turned to that other, it would sadden and grieve him. Had his motive been religion, he would have thanked God, the Most High, that God, the Most High, relieved him of this important matter through another. Then Satan, with all that, does not leave him and says: "Your grief is only due to the cessation of reward [al-thawab] for you, not because the faces of the people turned away from you to another. For had they heeded your words, you would have been the one rewarded, and your grief over missing the reward is praiseworthy." And the wretched one does not know that his submission to the truth [al-haqq] and his entrusting of the matter is better, and a more abundant reward, and a greater refuge for him in the Hereafter [al-Akhirah] than his sole distinction.

a.g: [They are] those whose effort is lost in worldly life, while they think that they are doing well in work."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
قال الله تعالى "وهم يحسبون أنهم يحسنون صنعاً -، وهذا أيضاً يرجع إلى العجب بالعمل. وقد يعجب الإنسان بالعمل هو مخطئ فيه كما يعجب بعمل هو مصيب فيه.
Indeed, God the Exalted has said, "And they think that they are doing good [ahsanu sun'an]," and this also returns to self-admiration [al-'ujb] with the deed. And a person may admire a deed in which he is mistaken, just as he may admire a deed in which he is correct.

a.g: Those are the ones who disbelieve in the verses of their Lord and in [their] meeting Him, so their deeds have become worthless; and We will not assign to them on the Day of Resurrection any importance.
That is their recompense - Hell - for what they denied and [because] they took My signs and My messengers in ridicule.
Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds - they will have the Gardens of Paradise as a lodging,
Wherein they abide eternally. They will not desire from it any transfer.
Say, "If the sea were ink for [writing] the words of my Lord, the sea would be exhausted before the words of my Lord were exhausted, even if We brought the like of it as a supplement."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
والمانع من ذكر هذا اتساعه وكثرته وانشعاب أبوابه الخارجة عن الحصر والنهاية، إذ ما من ذرة من أعلى السموات إلى تخوم الأرضين إلا وفيها عجائب آيات تدل على كمال قدرة الله تعالى وكمال حكمته ومنتهى جلاله وعظمته، وذلك مما لا يتناهى " قل لو كان البحر مداداً لكلمات ربي لنفد البحر قبل أن تنفد كلمات ربي " فالخوض فيه انغماس في بحار علوم المكاشفة ولا يمكن أن يتطفل به على علوم المعاملة، ولكن يمكن الرمز إلى مثال واحد على الإيجاز ليقع التنبيه لجنسه.
Indeed, what prevents the mention of this is its vastness and its multitude, and the branching of its doors which are beyond enumeration and limit, for there is not a single particle from the highest heavens to the depths of the earths except that within it are wondrous signs [ayat] which point to the perfection of the power [qudra] of Allah, the Exalted, and the perfection of His wisdom [hikma], and the ultimate majesty [jalaal] and greatness ['azama] of Him. And that is of what has no end. "Say: If the sea were ink for the words of my Lord, the sea would be exhausted before the words of my Lord were exhausted." Therefore, to delve into it is to plunge into the seas of the sciences of unveiling ['ulum al-mukashafa], and it is not possible to intrude with it upon the sciences of transaction ['ulum al-mu'amala]. However, it is possible to allude to a single example with brevity, so that an alertness to its kind may occur.

a.g: Say, "I am only a man like you, to whom has been revealed that your god is one God. So whoever would hope for the meeting with his Lord - let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
الباب الثاني فى الاخلاص وفضيلته وحقيقته ودرجاته فضيلة الإخلاص قال الله تعالى (وما أمروا إلا ليعبدوا الله مخلصين له الدين) وقال (ألا لله الدين الخالص) وقال تعالى (إلا الذين تابوا وأصلحوا واعتصموا بالله وأخلصوا دينهم لله) وقال تعالى (فمن كان يرجو لقاء ربه فليعمل عملا صالحا ولا يشرك بعبادة ربه أحدا) نزلت فيمن يعمل لله ويحب أن يحمد عليه وقال النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم: (ثلاث لا يغل عليهن قلب رجل مسلم إخلاص العمل لله) وعن مصعب بن سعد عن أبيه قال ظن أبى أن له فضلا على من هو دونه من أصحاب رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم فقال النبى صلى الله عليه وسلم (إنما نصر الله عز وجل هذه الأمة بضعفائها ودعوتهم وإخلاصهم) وعن الحسن قال قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم (يقول الله تعالى الإخلاص سر من سرى استودعته قلب من أحببت من عبادى) وقال على بن أبى طالب كرم الله وجهه (لاتهتموا لقلة العمل واهتموا للقبول فإن النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم قال لمعاذ بن جبل أخلص العمل يجزك منه القليل) وقال عليه السلام (ما من عبد يخلص لله العمل أربعين يوما إلا ظهرت ينابيع الحكمة من قلبه على لسانه) وقال عليه الصلاة والسلام (أول من يسئل يوم القيامة ثلاثة رجل آتاه الله العلم فيقول الله تعالى ما صنعت فيما علمت فيقول يارب كنت أقوم آناء الليل وأطراف النهار فيقول الله تعالى كذبت وتقول الملائكة كذبت بل أردت أن يقال فلان عالم ألا فقد قيل ذلك ورجل آتاه الله مالا فيقول الله تعالى لقد أنعمت عليك فماذا صنعت فيقول يارب كنت أتصدق به آناء الليل وأطراف النهار فيقول الله تعالى كذبت وتقول الملائكة كذبت بل أردت أن يقال فلان جواد ألا فقد قيل ذلك ورجل قتل في سبيل الله تعالى فيقول الله تعالى ماذا صنعت فيقول يارب أمرت بالجهاد فقاتلت حتى قتلت فيقول الله كذبت وتقول الملائكة كذبت بل أردت أن يقال فلان شجاع ألا فقد قيل ذلك قال أبو هريرة ثم خبط رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم فخذى وقال يا أبا هريرة أولئك أول خلق تسعر نار جهنم بهم يوم القيامة) فدخل راوى هذا الحديث على معاوية وروى له ذلك فبكى حتى كادت نفسه تزهق ثم قال صدق الله إذ قال (من كان يريد الحيا
Indeed, Tawus and others among the Successors narrated that a man asked the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, about one who does good [ma'ruf]—or he said, gives charity—and loves to be praised and rewarded, so he did not know what to say to him until there was revealed: "So whoever hopes for the meeting with his Lord, let him do righteous work [amal salih] and not associate anyone in the worship of his Lord." And he had intended both reward [ajr] and praise [hamd] together. And He, the Exalted, said: ("So whoever hopes for the meeting with his Lord, let him do righteous work and not associate anyone in the worship of his Lord.") It was revealed concerning one who acts for Allah and loves to be praised for it.
